titleInfo.title: Lorri A. Burgess oral history interview

mods.abstract: Burgess describes growing up and attending school in South Baton Rouge, her involvement in social services, community and church organizations, and her passion for improving the quality of life for Baton Rouge residents.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.1617. A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Natalie Clark.

Lorri Burgess was born in Baton Rouge, La., in 1963. She attended elementary and high school in South Baton Rouge, graduated from Louisiana State University in 1986, and then completed the paralegal studies program at LSU. She won her first election in 1996 and served three terms as the Metropolitan Councilwoman for District 10. Burgess was Baton Rouge's first elected African-American Mayor Pro-Tempore. The many organizations with which she has been involved include the Baton Rouge Center for World Affairs, the Greater Baton Rouge Port Commission, YWCA Encore Plus, the Sickle Cell Anemia Foundation, Sisters Supporting Sisters, and the McKinley High Alumni Association.
